title: Wednesday, 11th April, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:05 am
BE11:05am

So which picture of Zuck should we start with?

Nately Ahoy
VV75 morning
DRichi Good Morning
Blank canvas good morning everyone
Paper Chase Hullo
rw42 Got any where he doesn't look like a visiting alien?
Soundbuy Morning all
Airborne Cigar Is there a South Park version?
Binocular Phillip IV will do.
FATDAZ most people in my twitter stream were comparing him to a robot after his testimony
Peace and Love @rw42 Haha
BE11:07am

Frankly, i haven't seen enough of Zuck over the past 12 hours, with his nervy fratboy expression and his waxy face and his oddly Berlusconi hair.

J L Morning
BE11:08am

It's sort of dismal that we get five hours of testimony and the thing most people take away from it is, "hey that guy's a bit awk."

11:08 am
BE11:08am

But then, that perhaps reflects the questioning as much as the answering.

A. M. Morning all.
FATDAZ I wonder how much of his wealth is not tied up in $FB
pancakes or waffles Having watched parts of the testimony, I have to say some of the questioning was very tame
A. M. To quote the FT:Mr Zuckerberg told senators he agreed that “we have a broader responsibility than what the law requires” to police the platform
pancakes or waffles Maybe it was because there were so many senators and each of them only have 5-10 mins for questioning so there was no time to get into depth
BE11:09am

https://twitter.com/petridishes/status/983827243079229440

BE11:10am

Yep.

A. M. Doesn't say what responsibility, or that they've acted in accordance with it. Utter waffle (no offence @pancakes or waffles)
pancakes or waffles none taken!
11:10 am
BE11:10am

(@Pancakes: if you had ten minutes with Zuck, what would your first question be?)

Peace and Love This abysmal testimony was just another example that the USA are everything but fit and proper to lead a democratic free world
BE11:11am

Full story is ... wait, I've lost it ....

Soundbuy Why haven't you fired your hairdresser?
BE11:11am

https://www.ft.com...-b7e0-52972418fec4

rw42 https://pbs.twimg.com/media/DaflKGiXkAEEq80.jpg
11:12 am
BE11:12am

Market reaction pretty tame. FB shares up 5% or so during the session, for ...... reasons?

pancakes or waffles I would probably direct my line of questioning about how Zuckerberg feels he can reconcile gathering as much data on people as possible as the core part of FB's business model and privacy
pancakes or waffles I neither agree nor disagree, I am just curious to know
A. M. @pancake -- isn't that their business model? gather as much data, identify how to make the most out of it?
pancakes or waffles @A.M. that's what I mean, how does FB reconcile that with their newfound stance of "we care about privacy"
BE11:13am

Flattened out a bit after hours. Want some sellside? That'll enlighten us I'm sure.

BE11:13am

Citi:

A. M. @pancake hand-caught-in-cookie-jar posturing.. nothing more.
11:14 am
BE11:14am

We believe investors were likely reacting to a view that comments from several members of Congress suggested that the threat from over-regulation was less than feared (i.e., parenthetically, several members’ views could be interpreted as “we don’t want to over-regulate to a point where we stifle innovation” and “if Facebook can’t or won’t fix the issues, we may have to”). Investors also likely reacted favorably to
Zuckerberg’s poise and solutions-based answers. We note, however, that while new regulations in the U.S. may not materially impact Facebook’s business, other factors still could, including: 1) proactive changes Facebook itself makes, 2) pending regulatory changes in Europe related to GDPR, and/or 3) fines by the FTC relate to a possible violation to an existing consent decree. While we expect near-term volatility to persist (mixed user metrics, regulatory headlines, uncertainty about the impact of data limits on ad spend & prices, etc.), we believe Facebook has and will make the changes that its users and regulators want it to make and that these changes will ultimately make the platform stronger. For long-term minded investors, we believe the recent sell-off represents an opportunity and maintain our Buy rating.

pancakes or waffles If I had more time as well, I would also like to find out more about which features of FB are set as "opt-in" by default and not - from what I gather, it seems like most features are, by default, sharing data w/ FB unless you actively select not to
JimboRock Zuck: Yeah so if you ever need info about anyone at HarvardZuck: Just ask.Zuck: I have over 4,000 emails, pictures, addresses, SNS[Redacted Friend's Name]: What? How'd you manage that one?Zuck: People just submitted it.Zuck: I don't know why.Zuck: They "trust me"Zuck: Dumb f..ks.
FATDAZ Re $FB on guy I follow made the very telling point that the very people grilling Zuck alos empowered the NSA to collect as much data on NON US and US citizens as they could covertely at least to begin with so post and kettles
BE11:16am

Look -- I don't want to swim against the tide of journalistic commentary, but is this the most boring corporate scandal of our time?

pancakes or waffles @A.M. agreed. Mr. Zuckerberg's comments on having the "right" regulation as well, I don't feel like he did a great job @ communicating what is the "right" form - he just listed some examples FB did that were mostly in reaction to what has unfolded over the last few weeks
A. M. @FATDAZ: well, there is still a difference between "protect the country" (which might be a worn-out excuse) and "sell more ads to people"
BE11:17am

It's about the T&Cs of a website, without any clear indication how the use and possible abuse of those T&Cs affected a single actual person.

Pseudonym Surely everyone knew that FB was flogging their data off so people could advertise things at them?
FATDAZ @BE agreed everyone acts as though they were surprised when in fact modt people knew or didnt care and were complicit through inertia or laziness
Pseudonym It actually seems to have been operating as intended by everyone.
A. M. @Pseudonym: knew on a conceptual level, but I guess that was before the CA head did his 'bond-villain sans-cat' shtick.
11:18 am
BE11:19am

Meh. I'm sure I'm missing the big picture. That picture being Pepe Silvia standing in front of a cork board.

undefined
Electric Dragon Alexandra Petri is a treasure
DRichi Were there any questions about fake news and Russians getting Trump elected? (That's more interesting than a T&C Q&A)
Paper Chase Talking of less boring fangs, just read Jamie Powell's Amazon piece. Reasonable arguments there.
BE11:20am

(Wait, no, it's Charlie. The cork board's about Pepe Silvia. Bah.)

pancakes or waffles I think the bigger concern seems to be more around how FB protects that data (very loosely it seems), as opposed to actually having it in the first place ... it has been well-know, obviously, for some time that FB flaunts around individual privacy concerns
Waterloo Disagree BE. Changes lots of business models if they have to be explicit. Also they are yet to ask about data loss. Once it's been taken, they no longer have control on how it's used.
Pseudonym Remember the "swift boat veterans for truth"? Fake news getting the pres in is not new.
11:20 am
BE11:20am

Anyway .... to markets.

Impressive top-line growth has been driven partly via acquisition and partly via new growth initiatives. However, this growth has come at the expense of higher capital intensity and represents a fundamental shift in the capital-light business model. Factoring in operating leases, we see a company with mediocre returns, limited value creation and increasing balance sheet risk.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

In N+1 Singer’s recent Trend Spotting note (Synchronicity II, 27 March), we stated that BCA’s YTD de-rating fails dismally
to take account of the favourable channel shift in the Used car market and BCA’s market position given its unique
physical auction and data platform. Today’s update supports our view, with strong performance continuing through
H2. Full year PBT and ND are expected to be ahead of market expectations. With the stock having de-rated to a P/E of
just 13x and the yield now up to 5.6%, upgrades of c3% should be a positive catalyst for the share price and put its
growth potential across the UK and especially Europe back in the spotlight. We re-iterate our BUY stance and look
forward to the release of its full year results on 28 June which will provide more detail on these growth dynamics.

BE11:30am

The PBT range for FY18 was £107-112m (cons £109m) so we would expect forecasts to increase towards the upper end
of the range today, potentially a 3% upgrade for us (from £108m to £111m). Helped by this and possibly other w/c
related movements, guidance is also for net debt to be lower than expected (cons was £260m adjusting for securitised
partner finance debt). These results underline the reasons for our positive view on the stock and highlight that recent
share price weakness is anomalous to its growth path. With the forward P/E having fallen back to just 13x and the yield
up to 5.6% (FCF yield now 8% adjusting for Partner Finance), today’s news should trigger a reasonable bounce in the
share price and we re-iterate our BUY stance.

SocGen with the summary.

BE11:34am

Solid FY18 EBIT margin trend in UK/ROI Tesco this morning reported 2.4% 4Q
UK/ROI LFL sales growth, consistent with the +2.0% trend over the Christmas period and
in line with consensus on 2.2%. A highlight for us is the solid operating performance in
FY18, with £1,644m group EBIT before exceptionals, 3% above consensus £1,600m,
reflecting margin improvement in all geographies. UK/ROI FY18 EBIT before exceptionals
at £1,053m is 5% above consensus on £996m, reflecting 50bp EBIT margin improvement
in FY18, beating consensus on c. +40bp and SGe +31bp. This is a robust performance
given the challenging trading environment in the UK due to higher input costs and SG&A
cost inflation, particularly wage increases.

'On track' to deliver 3.5%-4.0% operating margins… this could be one year early! Group operating margin in H2 was 3.0% with 42bps H2 improvement in the UK and the rate of improvement accelerating. A similar step up in the UK next year could see Tesco already within the 3.5%-4.0% guidance next year. Management increasingly talking about a focus on cash generation and 'sustainable returns to shareholders' (i.e. think buy-backs/special divis).

BE11:47am

A post quarter-end review of our valuation models and macro assumptions
(including a 9$ increase in our 2018E Brent assumption) has driven a 10$ average
increase in our sector price Targets. This, combined with diverse year-to-date share
price performance (ranging between -20$ and +19$), leads to several rating
changes under our relative rating methodology – Aker Bp (EFI from OFI), faroe
petroleum (uFI from OFI), Ophir Energy (OFI from EFI) and premier Oil (EFI from
uFI). FIith the coverage group now averaging implied returns of 20$ and estimated
to be pricing in a long-term oil price of $52⁄bbl ($17⁄bbl less than spot prices and
$11⁄bbl below the forward curve for 2019), we also change our Industry FFiew to
Neutral from Negative. A firmer oil price outlook, rising cash flows and increased
access to capital markets have eroded balance sheet concerns. This in turn is
allowing investors and sector management teams to focus on forward plans for new
developments, rather than budget cuts and debt covenants. A continuation of $65-
70⁄bbl oil should generate further upside to debt-levered producers, but we see the
greatest value opportunities in those stocks where asset-specific risks are causing
investors to remain cautious: ¢airn Energy (Indian tax arbitration), Ophir Energy
(fortuna fLNg sanction) being two clear examples. The larger, more liquid
European E&ps with high-quality assets (Aker Bp, Lundin petroleum, Tullow Oil) all
trade at a premium to the broader peer group. FIhile we believe this is entirely
rational, we feel relative outperformance for these names depends on the extent to
which investors’ risk appetite prompts a re-allocation from the European Integrated
Oils in search of greater growth and commodity price leverage.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

We expect Tullow to provide a trading update ahead of its AGM. At its FY17 results, Tullow guided to
2018 production of 86-95kboe/d (including 10.2kboe/d implied contribution from Jubilee insurance
proceeds) and therefore a key focus will be the production performance at both TEN and Jubilee in 1Q.
With net debt at end-2017 of $3.5bn, de-leveraging will continue in 2018 driven by organic FCF and the
completion of the Ugandan farm down in 1H18. In addition, Tullow continues to work towards derisking
the South Lokichar Basin development in Kenya during 2018. Exploration activity is set to
remain limited with the key well (Cormorant offshore Namibia) likely to spud in 2H18.

BE12:02pm

Citi incoming.

BE12:02pm

Citi's Take — ASOS has reported 1H profits in line with expectations but against a
very strong comp 2Q sales growth of +21% is below consensus expectations (cons
+28%). Investment in business has been increased with US hub opening in July
rather than the autumn and therefore capex guidance has been raised again to
£230-250m (from £220m) and is likely to stay at this level for a couple of years, (Citi
£200m) limiting FCF generation until after FY20e and therefore company are
finalizing a £150m RCF.

BE12:02pm

Implications — August 2018 consensus PBT unlikely to change — On the back
of this statement, we do not expect consensus forecasts to change materially. For
the record, we have a £100m August 2018e PBT (EPS 97.1p, +26.8% yoy). This
assumes +30% sales growth and a +40bps increase in retail gross margin over the
full year. Consensus forecast c.£101m PBT.
 Investment case — The weakness of the US$ will start to drag on sales growth
and the departure of the CFO may create disruption after three years of stability.
The business is less profitable than the market credits it for and we are concerned
that it is still not investing enough in future growth. Neutral rated.
 Neutral, target price £77.50 — Our £77.50 target price is based on a 10-year DCF,
incorporating a +17.5% sales CAGR (2017-27e) and a terminal EBIT margin of
8.0%, in line with peers. This target price is equivalent to 2.05 EV/sales and 64x PE
for 2019e.

Management remains confident that its investments will continue to

25%, the additional spend supporting an acceleration of infrastructure

new finance system was introduced (£40m, £15m more than expected), and 2) tight
stock on the transition to Eurohub2. Reflecting these factors, as well as a stock build
to improve availability, we now expect FY18 net cash of c.£35m (from c.£100m) and a
further cash outflow in FY19, before ASOS returns to FCF positive in FY20.
